Award.AwardTitle: Facilitating Remote Participation at International Scientific Conferences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Effective dissemination of the results of scientific research is critically important to progress in all areas of inquiry. Isolation from one another slows progress, creating expensive redundant effort around the globe. Open exchange of findings is a cornerstone of the scientific community, and for the individual scientist, in linguistics and beyond, participation in that exchange grows more important, but also more challenging, as cutting-edge research becomes both more interdisciplinary, and more international, than at any time in history. The number and diversity of workshops and conferences that active researchers feel a responsibility to participate in is exploding around the world. This is by and large positive, of course, but it also places an increasingly unsustainable burden on many scientists that by all rights should be included in these critical conversations. International travel, rewarding as it may be, is also time-consuming and expensive. For those with disabilities, it may be prohibitively difficult. For scholars from institutions with fewer resources, or from less wealthy parts of the world, finances may derail otherwise sound travel plans. Other commitments, such as those to family, or local academic and administrative responsibilities, further compete for the time necessary to attend meetings. Visa restrictions add to this expense and effort, and sheer geographic remoteness is often sufficient to convince would-be conference attendees to stay home instead. In some cases, technology already exists to allow participants to bridge the travel issue and participate remotely in scientific gatherings. At least in linguistics, however, these technologies, owing in large part to their expense and unfamiliarity, tend to be deployed, if at all, in a limited fashion, around the margins of most meetings. Remote participants therefore miss out on most of the key scientific discussion taking place at these meetings.

This proposal presents a plan to pilot, at the upcoming Speech Prosody 2016 conference at Boston University, a suite of solutions that will enable members of the scientific community to participate in conference activities as fully from remote locations as from the host location itself. Data will be collected concerning the usability and attractiveness of each technology, and will be used to devise a future budget model whereby such remote participation strategies can one day become self-funding. Specifically, this project will implement remote participation solutions for the following scenarios: 1) discussion and Q&A during oral sessions; 2) remote presentation of posters; 3) active attendance and interaction during poster sessions, and 4) "passive" attendance at oral and poster sessions, both in real time, and after the fact via digital archives of the proceedings. Solutions include streaming video, stationary iPads at posters, and mobile telepresence robots. A dynamic post-conference proceedings package featuring video archiving and asynchronous discussion forums will promote sustained interaction after the conference. Ultimately, this works aims to move not just linguistics, but other fields as well, toward a standard of remote participation that can become the norm at meetings, workshops, and conferences around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this project was to use the Speech Prosody 8 conference, held at Boston University from May 31 to June 3, 2016, as a proving ground for a range of new strategies and technologies to make remote participation in scientific meetings and conferences more effective and more accessible. Even in a relatively narrowly defined academic specialization like prosody, in any given year there are already more high-impact conferences and workshops taking place around the world than even the most mobile, carefree, and generously subsidized among us could ever contemplate attending. Travel is wonderfully enriching, and necessary, but it can also be expensive, exhausting, and time-consuming. For those with disabilities, it can be prohibitively difficult. For scholars from institutions with fewer resources, or from less wealthy parts of the world, finances may derail otherwise sound travel plans. Other commitments, such as those to family, or local academic and administrative responsibilities, further compete for the time necessary to attend meetings. Visa restrictions add to this expense and effort, and sheer geographic remoteness is often sufficient to convince would-be conference attendees to stay home instead. At the same time, dissemination of results is critical to our common enterprise. Isolation slows progress, creating expensive redundant effort around the globe. Open exchange of findings is a cornerstone of our scientific community.

While it is already relatively common for a few presenters at each conference to deliver their talks from remote locations via Skype or similar video-conferencing platforms, remote participation options still rarely go much beyond this. We were interested first in trying out a range of remote participation options, surveying people before and after the conference about how they felt about having such options available at conferences, and perhaps most importantly gauging what if anything potential remote participants would be willing to pay for such services. The goal ultimately is to find a financial model for offering such often costly services that won’t need to rely exclusively on funding agencies like NSF, or on the often fickle largesse of host institutions. 

The options for remote participation in Speech Prosody that we offered were the following: Authors of oral presentations were invited to present from remote locations using video-conferencing software, as is relatively common. For remote viewing of oral presentations, we offered live-streaming of all oral sessions at the conference, and then after the fact, we segmented this captured audio and video into chunks corresponding to individual talks, and made these available on the conference’s “detailed program” website, where clicking on a link for each talk in the schedule brings viewers to a separate page for that talk, where an abstract, a four-page paper, and video of the talk, along with slides from the presentation, if the authors chose to share them, were made available. Authors presenting posters were also offered the opportunity to do this remotely. In this case, we printed authors’ posters locally, hung them in the presentation hall with the other posters, and then affixed an iPad with a Skype connection to the posterboard, such that viewers and authors could see one another, and interact. Lastly, remote attendance at poster sessions, challenging for obvious reasons, were offered by means of two mobile telepresence robots. Remote viewers were able to virtually “inhabit” these robots, and then maneuver them around the presentation hall from poster to poster, as their interests demanded. Denizens of each robot were able to interact with poster presenters (and with other robots) during the course of the poster session. 

In post-conference surveys, participants reported that they would appreciate the opportunity to attend remotely only when there were barriers to in-person attendance (cost, health, time). Participants observed that current technology still does not present a seamless experience and attenuated audio and lack of facial expressions made full engagement difficult, both in the oral presentations and during the less conventional poster sessions. Responses from surveys after the event indicated that participants reported that remote participation detracted more from the conference experience than they had anticipated in a pre-conference survey (61% to 41%). However, responses concerning the appropriate registration rate for remote participation did not change with the experience (about half the conference registration fee). In addition, the acceptable percentage of remote presentations at a given conference decreased after the event (from 29% to 22% for oral presentations but just 30% to 27% for posters).
